learning_outcomes.description: Work well in groups and as an individual to produce thoughtful and complex analyses of key issues in the humanities today, as well as suggestions for addressing these issues.

Write sophisticated and extended analyses of an important issue in the humanities showing original research, clear and coherent writing skills, clear and coherent structure, and a valid and coherent argument.
Speak effectively and clearly, both as an individual and as part of a team, to present the results of team research towards the addressing of a major issue in the humanities today.
Identify key issues facing the world today, and address the implications of these issues for the humanities, for academia, and for the wider society.
Effectively network with industry figures inside and outside UQ.
Understand and discuss a wide range of approaches to the big questions and issues facing the humanities and the world today.

assessments.task_description: Participation is essential for passing this course, and requires you to interact respectfully and learn from your peers. Students are expected to participate in seminar discussions and relevant seminar tasks, as well as the preparation for the annual symposium. This assessment requires you to show evidence of preparation for seminars and participate in large and small group discussions with relevant and well-focused comments. Interaction on Padlet is not essential, but will earn you additional points.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
Pitch 1 2/03/2026 - 20/03/2026

Pitch 2 23/03/2026 - 2/04/2026

Pitch 3 13/04/2026 - 24/04/2026

Pitch 4 27/04/2026 - 1/05/2026

Submit as a group through Blackboard by 2 pm. Only one group member needs to submit.
assessments.task_description:
THIS IS A SET OF FOUR GROUP ASSIGNMENTS. Students will work in their assigned seminar groups to prepare a series of pitches for the final course symposium. The pitches should be made using a variety of formats, including video, image production and text (appropriate video and imaging software will be provided through Adobe Creative Suites).


PITCH 1: (40%) SUBMITTED ON 20/3/26: in your first short VIDEO pitch of 3-5 minutes, each team should introduce a topic idea, address its strength, interest and originality, its relevance to more than one disciplinary perspective and its potential in fostering discussion between humanities scholars and the general public. 


PITCH 2: (30%) SUBMITTED ON 2/4/26: in your second short VIDEO pitch of 2-3 minutes, each team should propose an appropriate format to their symposium, and 3-4 possible speakers among UQ staff AND/OR international academic communities.


PITCH 3: (20%) SUBMITTED ON 24/4/26: in this pitch, your group should provide a draft POSTER, and 150-200 word advertising TEXT for the symposium,


PITCH 4: (10%) SUBMITTED ON 1/5/26: in this pitch, your group should compose two TEMPLATE EMAIL invitations for the symposium - one for students and staff you know well, and one for VIP guest, along with a list of VIP guests. You should also compose a set of 4 advertising social media posts and/or video clips.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Interview & Feature Story on Humanities Champion
assessments.category: Essay/ Critique, Project, Reflection, Role play/ Simulation
assessments.task_description:
For this assignment you should select and interview a 'humanities champion', and write a feature profile story about them based on this interview, reflecting on their professional path and development.  A 'humanities champion' can be an academic or a member of the general community whose research inspires you, and the profile story should discuss their education, past work experience, research and/or community engagement, aspirations and goals.


To verify that you conducted an interview, you will be required to submit a transcript of the conversation. This text will, however, not be considered in the grading of your feature story, or be calculated into your final word count.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
In this critical reflection on ONE BIG QUESTION IN THE HUMANITIES, you are required to write a critical and reflective essay (ca 2,000) on ONE of the issues discussed in the course, considering more than one perspective (e.g. looking at the two different aspects presented on each of the issues in the course) and making use of appropriate secondary reading material from the course and/or acquired through independent study. This could include the readings on disciplinarity, cultures of knowledge, difference and diversity and/or other themes studied throughout the course.


You should also integrate a discussion of your personal relationship or 'stake' in this issue, addressing why it is important to you, and your future plan/pathway. You will be instructed how to do this efficiently in the course.


In order to verify that it your research is all your own work, you must submit an essay plan outlining your sources and schedule a discussion with the course coordinator in week 13 or revision week. Your essay will receive an automatic fail if you have not submitted a plan or attended a discussion session, and your final essay must not deviate from your plan.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Introduction to the Course

What Humanities? What Big Questions?

Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg


Learning outcomes: L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Introduction to the Course What Humanities? What Big Questions? Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Humanities Today, Part 1

How do we shape our futures? Discussion Panel on UN's 'Sustainable Development Goals' and the Future of Work.

Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg

Guest Interviews: Yvonne Oberhollenzer & Sophie Plunkett

Tutorials: Introduction to Symposium Group Work

Required Seminar Reading: UN 'Sustainable Development Goals', Extract from Lauren Berlant, Cruel Optimism (2016)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Humanities Today, Part 1 How do we shape our futures? Discussion Panel on UN's 'Sustainable Development Goals' and the Future of Work. Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg Guest Interviews: Yvonne Oberhollenzer & Sophie Plunkett Tutorials: Introduction to Symposium Group Work Required Seminar Reading: UN 'Sustainable Development Goals', Extract from Lauren Berlant, Cruel Optimism (2016)

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Humanities Today, Part 2

This we will discuss a mix of humanities perspectives on what the humanities ARE, and what we contribute to society.

Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg

Interviews: Mix of interviews about the BIG QUESTIONS in the humanities.

Tutorials: Continuing work on Symposium Pitch

Required Reading: Michel Foucault, Introduction to 'The Archeology of Knowledge' (1969)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Humanities Today, Part 2 This we will discuss a mix of humanities perspectives on what the humanities ARE, and what we contribute to society. Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg Interviews: Mix of interviews about the BIG QUESTIONS in the humanities. Tutorials: Continuing work on Symposium Pitch Required Reading: Michel Foucault, Introduction to 'The Archeology of Knowledge' (1969)

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Big Question: Artificial Intelligence

This week we turn to our first big question, Artificial Intelligence. We will discuss whether we can truly call it intelligence and whether we need to introduce a new form of ethics with regards to it.

Interviews: Professor Nic Carah & Professor Heather Zwicker

Tutorials: Finalisation of symposium pitch

Required Watching: Alex Garland, Ex Machina (2014)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Big Question: Artificial Intelligence This week we turn to our first big question, Artificial Intelligence. We will discuss whether we can truly call it intelligence and whether we need to introduce a new form of ethics with regards to it. Interviews: Professor Nic Carah & Professor Heather Zwicker Tutorials: Finalisation of symposium pitch Required Watching: Alex Garland, Ex Machina (2014)

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Big Question: Erasure of the Past

We will continue discussing artificial intelligence, but in the light of much older cultural debate - the 'big issue' of heritage and iconoclasm and the question of whether there is such a thing as authenticity and cultural value in and of itself.

Guest Lecturer: Professor Alastair Blanshard

Tutorials: Professor Blanshard will potentially join our discussions in class, and we will start working on your speaker videos for the symposium.

Required Reading: Walter Benjamin, 'The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction' (1935) & Madeline H. Caviness, 'Iconoclasm and Iconophobia: Four Historical Case Studies' (2003)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 5: Big Question: Erasure of the Past

Guest Lecturer: Professor Alastair Blanshard Tutorials: Professor Blanshard will potentially join our discussions in class, and we will start working on your speaker videos for the symposium. Required Reading: Walter Benjamin, 'The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction' (1935) & Madeline H. Caviness, 'Iconoclasm and Iconophobia: Four Historical Case Studies' (2003)

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Big Question: The Limits of Artificial Intelligence

We will discuss the gig economy and the future work in an increasingly digital environment

Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg

Guest Interview: Associate Professor Elizabeth Stephens

Tutorials: We will finalise the speaker videos for the symposium.

Required Reading: Lilly Irani, "Difference and Dependence among Digital Workers: The Case of Amazon Mechanical Turk" (2015) AND Eric Limer, "My Brief And Curious Life As A Mechanical Turk" (2014)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 6: Big Question: The Limits of Artificial Intelligence

Required Reading: Lilly Irani, "Difference and Dependence among Digital Workers: The Case of Amazon Mechanical Turk" (2015) AND Eric Limer, "My Brief And Curious Life As A Mechanical Turk" (2014)
MID-SEMESTER BREAK No Seminars or Lectures

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Interview Workshop Week

During this week, which will focus on practical skills, you will have the opportunity to consider interview techniques and ask questions about your 'Interview & Feature Story on Humanities Champion' assessment.

Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg

Tutorial: During this tutorial you will also get some time to start working on your group's poster and advertising blurb for the Symposium.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05

Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg Tutorial: During this tutorial you will also get some time to start working on your group's poster and advertising blurb for the Symposium.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Big Question: Alternative Pasts

We will discuss how history (or histories) shape the heritage of modern humanities - especially with regards to Indigenous Australian histories.

Lecturer: Karin Sellberg

Guest Interview: r e a (University of Melbourne)

Tutorial: You will finalise your poster and blurbs.

Required Watching: Ann McGrath & Andrew Pikes, 'Message from Mungo' (2015)

Required Reading: Christine Judith Nicholls, Poles Apart by r e a: Re-Negotiating the Past through Visual Art (2010)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06

Required Watching: Ann McGrath & Andrew Pikes, 'Message from Mungo' (2015) Required Reading: Christine Judith Nicholls, Poles Apart by r e a: Re-Negotiating the Past through Visual Art (2010)

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Big Question: Climate Change

We will discuss the 'big issue' of wilderness and waste, and historical discourses of environment and land.

Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg

Interview:: Dr Amelia Hines (QUT)

Tutorials: We will work on your final symposium pitch - emails and social media advertising material.

Required Reading: Jack Halberstam, 'Chapter 1: Sex in the Wild' from Wild Things: The Disorder of Desire (2020) & Stuart Thompson, 'How plants reclaimed Chernobyl's poisoned land' (BBC, 2019)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06

Required Reading: Jack Halberstam, 'Chapter 1: Sex in the Wild' from Wild Things: The Disorder of Desire (2020) & Stuart Thompson, 'How plants reclaimed Chernobyl's poisoned land' (BBC, 2019)

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: QAGOMA VISIT

We will visit the Queensland Art Gallery during regular tutorial times this week. You will be given a worksheet to complete for your participation.

We also encourage all students to use the additional time available this week to schedule the interviews with their humanities champions.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Big Question: Culture Wars

We will discuss the concept of cancel culture, and examine the historical background of what is today referred to as 'culture wars' through the lens of the current political climate.

NOTE: This class can evoke strong emotions and we encourage students to refer to the student code of conduct when considering how to interact with each other and their teachers.

Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg

Tutorials: We will work in our groups to prepare for the symposium.

Required Reading: Sandy Stone, 'The Empire Strikes Back: A Posttranssexual Manifesto' (1992) & Sean Phelan, 'Seven theses about the so-called culture war(s)

(or some fragmentary notes on ‘cancel culture’)' (2025)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Big Question: Changing World Order

We will discuss the 'changing world order' that is increasingly becoming a big topic of conversation in international politics.

NOTE: This class can evoke strong emotions and we encourage students to refer to the student code of conduct when considering how to interact with each other and their teachers.

Lecturer: Dr Karin Sellberg

Guest Interview: Professor Richard Devetak

Tutorials: We will finalise our preparations for the symposium.

Required Reading: Selection from Judith Butler "What World Is This?: A Pandemic Phenomenology" (2022)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
